bibl.title: Letter from Sam [s.n.] to Atcheson Laughlin Hench and Philip Showalter Hench, October 15, 1940

div1.p: Sam thanks Philip Hench for the invitation to attend the Lazear memorial ceremony, but must stay home.

div1.head: Letter from Sam [s.n.] to Atcheson Laughlin Hench and Philip Showalter Hench, October 15, 1940
div1.opener:
UNION TANNING COMPANY
GREENBRIER TANNERY
MARLINTON, W. VA.
Oct, 15, 1940.
COPY
My dear Atcheson and Philip.
div1.p:
I had hoped to come to Washington on
the 26th, but things have happened here and are still in the air,
concerning the reoperation of Greenbrier Tannery, so I think it is
best that I stay around and be ready for what is liable to come.

It would be awful nice to come and esp-
ecially to see the several members of the family, and especially
to have the trip to and from with Atcheson, but as often happens
in your plans, its best for me to stay home this time.

I know you (Atcheson) are busy or you
would have written sooner, but just so you send me a football
setup, in a little while, and I will let you off. Just now I am
gathering nuts, have oodles of butter and wal-nuts and a few hick-
ory nuts and a few buckeys, and how I enjoy being in the woods and
seeing the beautiful foliage.

I know you (Philip) are busy also, and
I thank you for your invitation to come, and later when I do come, I wil
see your array of degrees and I will bring mine with me to show you
and the last one covers “lining the hymns in church”. Mary is well,
also Reuben, and if one of these days I get daubed up with lime, liq-
uor and extract, then I will smell just like I used to do, but I wil
look just the same. Hope we all get together some if these days, and
Mary joins in love to all of you, especially those girls and boys
whom I do love so much. Heres hoping you are all well, and always
we are glad to hear from you. I am mailing a dozen chestnuts to you
Philip, which will supply you individually on your roast party.
div1.closer: Lovingly, Uncle Sam. Nothing takes the place of Leather
